summary: Connor (Sean Patrick Flanery) and Murphy MacManus (Norman Reedus) have been living in Ireland for several years, working on a farm with their father (Billy Connolly). When they learn they've been charged with the murder of a Roman Catholic priest, the brothers travel to Boston to clear their names. Along the way, they meet Romeo (Clifton Collins Jr.), a street fighter who joins them in their quest to find Concezio Yakavetta (Judd Nelson), a mobster who they think is really behind the murder.

reviews.content:
After the MacManus twins, Connor (Sean Patrick Flanery) and Murphy (Norman Reedus), and their father, Noah "Il Duce" (Billy Connolly), assassinated Joe Yakavetta, they fled to Ireland. Eight years later, their uncle Father Sibeal arrives to inform them that a renowned Boston priest was murdered by a mysterious assassin who attempted to frame the Saints by using their ritual assassination style. In response, the twins dig up their old gear and weapons and depart for the United States. En route to Boston aboard a container ship, the twins meet a Mexican underground fighter named Romeo, who recognizes them as the Saints. Romeo convinces them to let him join them as their new partner. Hearing a radio broadcast regarding Joe's son, Concezio Yakavetta, they deduce that he must have hired the hitman who killed the priest to draw them out of hiding. Meanwhile, Detectives Greenly, Dolly, and Duffy are at the scene of the priest's murder. They are greeted by Special Agent Eunice Bloom, the protégée of Paul Smecker (who has died) who has been assigned to investigate the murder and determine whether or not the Saints are responsible. She comes to the conclusion that the Saints were not who murdered the cleric, and begins an investigation to find the real assassin. She and the other officers find out the assassin is Ottilio Panza, a man who appears to be working for a mysterious man known only as "The Old Man"...

Rotten Tomatoes consensus reads: "This sequel to the cult favorite The Boondock Saints is more of the same -- unoriginal, absurd, violent, over-the-top, and occasionally mean-spirited". (via Wikipedia)

The brothers are back and it´s the same silly cartoony actioneer setup as in the first one. Not much to like or care about.

The original Boondock Saints was hardly high art, but at least it's excessiveness, gratuitousness, and silliness was fun, with Willem Dafoe making the whole thing work by holding back nothing in his performance. With him gone, the film struggles to replicate any of the entertainment value that the original had in spades, bringing in Julie Benz as a carbon copy of his character but focusing explicitly on the stunts rather than the theatrics. Narrative pacing and content is sacrificed for fanservice and self-references. Couple that with the production value of a mid-budget porno and a lapse of nearly a decade between the release of the original and the sequel, and what you ultimately end up with is an incredibly disappointing and poor-quality follow-up that fails to attract fans of the cult classic original. This 'franchise' doesn't have the clout to leave such an open door for a sequel.

It's no exaggeration to say that the action in Boondock Saints II looks like a student film version of The Matrix. The reactions to being shot are like elementary school students on a playground. (1/5)

As usual, the sequel rarely lives up to the original.  However, if you enjoyed the original, than this sequel will not disappoint.  Same levels of violence, insolence and marginal morality.  A couple of surprises are thrown in for the fans, as well as a teaser for a trilogy entry.
While not for everyone it's for die hard fans of the cult classic that wants to see more from The Brothers
Some movies just don't need a sequel, The Boondock Saints is one of them. I like to pretend that this one doesn't exist.
Loved the first one. Absolutely hated this one.  Terrible everything.  I just cannot believe this is what Troy Duffy came up with after all those years... Absolute trash.
The family that prays together, stays together. The family that prays AND kicks bad-guys-butts together, locks and loads together! "In Nomine Patris..."
Terrible cringe horrible sequel that I'll forget about in t minus already forgot about it.

It was a little odd that the 1st movie ended seeming like the vigilanteism would continue, but instead they disappeared for 8 yrs. The crudeness in this sequel was less funny and more random. This had good action, but not as much plot. The end had an interesting surprise, but it is unfortunate the series will not be continued.
I don't remember this movie EVER being promoted. I just found out it existed in 2018.

people say this movie was mean spirited no shit it was they are fucking Irishmen we have a mean sense of humor and the characters were the same lovable goofballs from the first movie with some new characters. I will not spoil the ending but let's just say if the third movie focuses on where the second left off it's gonna be fun

I think the desire to make a sequel after the successful DVD sales was well-founded and had promise, but knowing they barely got the movie made had me reluctant to watch it - it turns out I could've done without viewing this. They rehash some of the highlights of the first movie but done in a lazier way. There was a glaring lack of rehearsal with the young version of Il Duce pulling the guns out of his vest. I did like that they provided him a backstory rather than just coming up with a McGuffin plotline to get the boys killing again, and some of the action scenes were well-choreographed.

Half a star for bringing back the McManus trio, half a star for Doc, and half a star for Duffy/Dolly/Greenly. Completely unoriginal, relying far too heavily on flashbacks and recalls to the first movie and then prison-fucking, dry, everything that made the first one great, ending by defecating, urinating and vomiting all over the sobbing and bleeding mess that's left. Rocco would rise from the dead and go Wyatt Fucken Earp all over this abomination if he could.

Don't get me wrong, the original was far from, well, original, but it did what it did beautifully and stylishly. It was a stroke of genius. It was, if you will, like a shot poured from a bottle of the finest whisky known to human kind. This, then, is the equivalent of someone pouring a second shot from the same bottle, then diluting it with water, cola, mud, piss, shit, vomit, and cornflour.
stunk never shouldve made it
They've ruined the franchise.
EAT MY ASS THIS MOVIE IS FUCKING GOD TIER, GO FUCK YOUR OWN MOTHER WITH A ROTTEN CACTUS

I liked seeing some of the same characters I loved in the first and the story had some really good moments but other than that it struggled. the writing was overall weak and cheesy and the dialogue was so bad. I'm not even sure there was ever a clear direction for the story and it shows. I wanted to like it but never could get past all the problems.
Terrible cringe horrible sequel that I'll forget about in t minus already forgot about it.
Not as good as the first but still a good movie in it's own.

Alright unlike the original, this movie is just cringy, relying on the old race joke one too many times throughout the film and setting up for a very strange ending (that may call for a sequel, but based on the box office response and even the audience score, may be unlikely). Too much random, unoriginal violence unlike the funny, over-the-top but still cute scenes from the original.
Just terrible...... :(

the boondock saints is one of my favorite movies. but this one is one of the worst movies. I just felt like the movie could of been made in 30 minutes. and that's how the movie felt to me. I just didn't like it it seemed scrambled and didn't make much sense.
This film was almost good.
This movie is amazing, as is the first one! These critics are retarded to think of the Boondock Saints franchise as anything other than amazing!
Can't wait for the third one!
A far cry from the original. Still, it's absurd and violent in the way fans of the first will enjoy.
Not as good as the original movie. It's a shame because i was looking forward to a sequel to the original cult classic film.

This is just about the worst movie I have ever seen. I loved the first one but this sequel is just an insult. Judd Nelson is a poor mans Al Pacino. The female FBI character is a Fem Bot version of Agent Starling and the Mexican side kick character is cringe worthy.

The "plot" is exhausting, choppy and schitzophrenic. The performances are all forced in attempt to make up for the horrible plot, bad sequencing and corny events.

Please dont further disgrace the memory of the original Boondock Saints with a third movie.
I enjoyed this movie it wasn't as good as the first one but it was still entertaining and I really want a third movie to round out the series.
The first movie was interesting. This was just plain pretentious. Never has a character irritated me so much as Julie Benz in this movie.
It wasn't as good as the first, but it had its moments.

Wow this one fell so far from the original... or did it? Is it possible the score to this film along with a much weaker visual style did this one in (Catwoman 2004 - changing that music and re-editing the existing footage; there is a much better film hidden in there) I had to check: bigger budget, same writer/director, music guy, one of the same producers & editors, different cinematographers and different production company (Stage 6 has a ton of  straight to home video sequel bombs; thanks Sony) 
I'm reading there's a sequel in development (Good for Norman Reedus albeit I'm sure Flanerly could use some of that TWD success rubbing off on him).  The original is my favourite sleeper cult classic I didn't see it in the theatre, never saw trailer just popped it in the DVD player one night on a word of mouth rental suggestion (sometime between 02 and 06). 
I like the idea of revisiting these characters; who doesn't want to root for the anti-hero Punisher style but really this one was best left in 1999 with the original.
Better than the original. Feel free to fight me.

Not nearly as good as the first film, this movie fails to create any new plot points or any new interest for the film. However, with the addition of characters like Romeo and the death of characters like Greenly, we; as the audience, cannot help but watch and, to some degree, enjoy what we are seeing.

If you thought the first film was bad, just wait until you waste hours of your life in one of the all time most pointless sequels in the history of cinema. Luckily, this killed an already laughably horrendous franchise.

Still fun - Connor (Flanery) & Murphy (Reedus) are still at it, taking down Boston gangsters, with some help from their Dad (Connolly) & Bloom (Benz). They're still charming and are aided by the comic sidekick, Romeo (Collins Jr). A little melodramatic at the end, but fast-paced and fum throughout, with plenty of shoot-em-ups!

A good movie and a good story but i think what really sort, well not dragged the movie down, but the fact they didn't have Rocco aka the funny man. I thought he brought good attention to the screen and knew how to make the audience laugh.

Has a more cohesive story then the first, but a lot of the cast that gave the first one its drive did not return or were demoted to cameos. A fun movie that takes itself a little too seriously for its own good

This is probably my favourite movie of all time. The characters are unique and have depth. I just cant. This movie is so good I'm actually having trouble describing it. You should watch it. What are you doing, go , go , do it, what are you waiting for?

This is a movie of two halves, in the first half the film kinda makes fun of itself and rehashes some of the stuff that made the first movie so god damn good. It slowly transforms into a prequel with some sequel scenes as well.  You can't just make a great sequel to a GREAT movie, if this movie had been first there would have been no one saying "It wasn't as good as the original" (I hate those people) The only problem I have with the film is the cowgirl accent from the lead detective... it's so overly drawn out that it takes from the scenes where she talks and makes me want to mute and read the movie.

Spoiler filled review

The sequel to Boondock Saints fails in many, many ways and answers the question Ã¢??Should I waste 1 hour and 58 minutes of my life watching the sophomore effortÃ¢???

Troy Duffy directed this movie as well as the original, now IÃ¢??m very curious about what happened to him to make him think this movie needed to be goofy.  It starts off decent with plenty of good story direction.  Although I could have done without seeing both brotherÃ¢??s asses in their shower in the barn Ã¢??suit upÃ¢?? montage.  By the way, during this Ã¢??get suited upÃ¢?? montage the priest just happens to be waiting with Il Duce (Connolly) like no time had passed?  It felt as if Mr. Duffy gave us the directorÃ¢??s cut.  In fact he didnÃ¢??t want to leave anything on the cutting room floor.  It was if he said Ã¢??Hey, I filmed all this extra material!  IÃ¢??m putting it in!Ã¢??.  By putting all this extra crap in the movie, it takes away from the storyline.

The acting was questionable by all but, most notably the 3 detectives.  Greenly, Duffy, & Dolly were written to be Ã¢??zanyÃ¢?? and was a pain to watch.  At times I felt that I was watching a Ã¢??fan filmÃ¢?? of the first movie.  LetÃ¢??s just say that I wasnÃ¢??t sad when the most annoying one got plugged.  Ã¢??thanksÃ¢?? for showing up!Ã¢??.  Special Agent Eunice (Julie Benz) was portrayed as this amazingly hot chick detective and they were pretty blatant about it.  SheÃ¢??s good looking and all but, the way the character was portrayed was pretty annoying.  I donÃ¢??t blame Benz at all though.  She has been in many TV series that IÃ¢??ve seen her in as well as Punisher: War Zone.  LetÃ¢??s just say she was hampered by the script.  Doc (Gerard Parks) should have been left out in this sequel of crap.  He is getting way to old to be hitting his marks.  I wasnÃ¢??t convinced at all that he actually had a stutter.  It was pretty sad.  I was afraid he was gonna get broke.  On the whole, the casting must have been handled by a homeless person because I was never able to buy Judd Nelson as a Italian crime boss nor could I stand Peter Fonda playing an old Italian man.  I mentioned Punisher: War Zone earlier and I felt that Judd was channeling Jigsaw at times and that was a mistake.  Horrible.  Judd Nelson, what has happened to you?  Oh, by the way the sausage hit that man in the chest but yet he had on headgear?  Horrible.

Villains.  Bad Guys.  Antagonist(s).  Well, no matter how many words you got this movie had it all.  In fact it had a 3 tier system.  I donÃ¢??t understand why their needed to be the focused effort on the first bad guy and how much he hated to be short.  I can understand a couple references to this but they actually filmed scenes where this was the focus.  Much like a video game, once the level boss was defeated you moved on to the Act II boss. Lame.  But I already said that.  And then so on until you get to fight the final boss Ã¢??The Italian FondaÃ¢??.  He must have put in his contract that he wouldnÃ¢??t stand at all or make any movements.  Ã¢??I must sit during my whole scene or you donÃ¢??t get none of this!Ã¢??  I will say that he made decent on the accent though.

The soundtrack is horribly lacking.  It has the 80Ã¢??s hair band sound with a couple of instances when it just cutÃ¢??s off when scenes are changed which feels awkward.  It feels like he hired a garage band to record the music.  What the heck is Ã¢??I want to be balls deep in your loveÃ¢????  The soundtrack shouldnÃ¢??t take you out of the movie like this.

LetÃ¢??s get back to Troy Duffy for our final thoughts.  There was a scene between Gorgeous George and a street level thug that went byJoJo.  The framing had JoJo falling out of frame many times and other times he was just cut off at the chin.  George was tall and JoJo was short so, what should Troy Duffy had done?  Fit them both in the frame!!!  If he would have put time into his actors, soundtrack, casting, framing, pacing, editing, and script then this had the potential to be decent.  The brotherÃ¢??s make this movie as they did before.  ItÃ¢??s just sad that they didnÃ¢??t have the director they needed to take the story to the next level.

Oh, and if I didnÃ¢??t mention you actorÃ¢??s that were in this movie.  Feel grateful.  I didnÃ¢??t have a problem with you.  Yes, IÃ¢??m talking to you Ã¢??Incon(spic)uousÃ¢??.  Oh, and Troy, next time take the first ending, you can take the second ending and make another piece of crap with that.

Comic Book Movie Plus:  Julie Benz Ã¢?? Punisher: War Zone, Peter Fonda Ã¢?? Ghost Rider, Willem Dafoe Ã¢?? Spider-Man

There is no "Bonus" for nudity in this case.  I didn't need to see the Brothers' asses.  But you girls might...

Its been ten long years sense Boondock Saints came out in 1999. Now that the second one has came out, and me being a huge fan of the first one my review might be a little bias. I liked this movie but it had nothing on the first on. Still funny. The cop chick was super annoying and some of the acting was way over the top. I really liked the back story of the Saints dad. If you liked the first on watch this one with low expectations and you will like it.
funny  and very good

Flannery and Reedus are effective as ever when the action turns up.
Holy shit this is bad!
Not as good as the second, but still solid nonetheless. Love to see the MacManus brothers crushing it in another action.

Yuck! I don't know what gives a more yuck feeling, the whole movie or Julie Benz's horrible accent, perhaps the latter. The sequel to the cult film tries to imitate the original in all sorts of ways and only leading to cliched, over the top and mostly a version lacking energy. Sean Patrick Flanery gives a terrible performance and the direction is unbearable. William Dafoe is also dearly missed and it's an insult to the original film.
Not as good as the first, but still better than most of the crap Hollywood churns out these days.

I liked this one almost as much as the 1st one. It brought back most all of the original cast and for a sequel that took 10 years to make, that is impressive! It's a new plot, but stays true to the original and is all around great for anyone who liked the first movie.
Stays true to the first one. A little more outrageous but not half bad. If you enjoyed the first, than this won't fail you.
Kind of corny, but that made it a little more fun to watch
Better than the first, can't wait for the third.
This one i liked a lot more than the first one.  The storylime was much better and it clearly explained the events leading up to becoming the "Boondock Saints".
awesome movie but original was better
Not as good as the first and more awful "ORISH" accents and it has an even bigger body count. Julie Benz gave me a major twitch.
This Sucked.The First Was So Much Better.This Was A Waste Of Time.This Doesn't Even Have A Lot Of Action.This Was A Terrible Sequel.F
just as entertaining as the first, if you're looking to watch this type of movie its exactly what you want to watch
big  let  down   from   the 1st  one,

Poor excuse for a sequel. The death blow was the decision to have Willem Dafoe appear only in the last seconds of the film. He stole every scene he was in in the original and his absence (or should I say substitution by the sexy FBI agent) was sorely felt. All in all, a mess of a film with virtually none of the original's gritty charm.
Not as good as the first but if your a fan of the saints its still worth watching.

(19%)
I haven't seen the first, and I'm not too sure if I want to after watching this. Main issue here is that they tried to cover up the crap plot with a thick helping of overblown garbage that stinks up all the movie's problems resulting in them being highlighted and clear. The two leads are an insult to 2D poorly fleshed comicbook characters, and the strong desire to be cool comes across as forced and annoying. The performances at times are acceptable for this type of thing, but the script is hampered by clueless dialogue and lackluster plot structure. Also, how many times can these Irish Jules from Pulp Fiction wannabes fire without reloading? Because I didn't know handguns had 2000 bullet capacity sized clips.
Not as interesting as the first movie, but still fun to watch...:)

I watched this movie mostly because of the fact that the great The Walking Dead actor Norman Reedus was in it.  It turns out, another one of my least favorite characters, Infinite Ammo, also had a major role in the film. For the majority of this movie I had no idea what was going on. Scenes repeated, there were flashbacks and cutscenes where you couldn't tell if it was one or not. Things just straight up didn't make sense most of the time, and it was way to confusing. Dreams, flashbacks, cutscenes, thoughts, and narratives made up the majority of the movie, so most of the time for me was spent trying to figure out what was real and happening and what wasnt. There where a lot of refrences to the first movie, often showing the same flashback scenes a few times. The fighting scenes weren't that great when they happened, just super heroic, impossable shootouts that I disliked, and nobody ever reloaded. It was really dumb at times how they tried to intergreat comedy into the movie, because I only laughted two times the whole movie and eveything else that was supposed to be funny was just stupid. I didn't like the ending or begining either, and mostly just didn't like the whole movie, not that I was expecting to much.
An average second part.

This movie did not live up to the first one, not even close. They thought using the same idea would work but it was executed terribly and was overly clichéd. 
Some problems with this:
1. They changed the lead investigator to a female with a terrible accent
2. The other cops used excessive profanity and were worried about getting in trouble over everything
3 The fight scenes were poorly written/ executed and were not as tight as the original and were very erratic.
Long story short, there are so many things that are wrong with this movie.
 If you are a fan of the first movie don't watch this one, it will almost ruin it for you. and is a waste of an hour and a half.

If you loved the original Boondock Saints, "All Saints Day" is a flawed but likable sequel.  The first half of the movie is pretty weak for its shameless attempts to follow the first movie way too closely, minus the sense of moral ambiguity that I enjoyed in the first film.  The last act is very strong though, fleshing out the backstory of the characters and providing some great twists that will make Saints fans cry and cheer.
nowhere near as good as the original but not terrible
Occasionally over the top, there is something oddly "honest" about it's brutality.  The ending is a nice twist that sets up possible future installments.
1972's The Godfather Is My Fourth Favorite Film Of All Time.
Decent but not as good as the first
I love that the 2nd one is just as good as the 1st. I can't wait for the 3rd!!! Just brilliant.
I don't know why this has such a bad rating, because I liked it as much as the first one if not more.
Rehashes everything from the original, whilst leaving fans with a disappointing conclusion.
it was good but to much comedy

I really don't understand the critic's hate for this movie (the franchise as a whole.) The movie doesn't boast great acting and the story isn't complex, but the movie is quite unique and enjoyable. Many compare it to Tarantino's work, and it's obvious it was inspired by it, but I think The Boondock Saints carved something all its own.

The Boondock Saints II has a lot of good going for it: the brothers are likable and have chemistry together, there is lots of funny (though uneven) dialogue, a great soundtrack, and stylish action sequences. 

Duffy did a great job of duplicating what what successful in The Boondock Saints, yet didn't stick to it religiously (this isn't a Hangover/Hangover 2 situation) There is obvious mirroring going on with the inclusion of a sidekick, the overly-dramatic special agent, etc. but it wasn't overly distracting.

I think the introduction of a secondary plot involving Poppa M's backstory was pretty cool. Again, the acting and plot is isn't very strong, but it's passable. I really think Duffy improved his directing int this. Benz, rather than Dafoe, is the main reason this movie isn't as good as the original. Benz character is VERY annoying.

I love that it makes several references to the original, even bring back Rocco in a dream sequence. I also really liked Romeo. It will be fun to see if they carry out the formula they have established so far in the franchise and added another sidekick in the sequel. 

In all, I definitely recommend, especially if you (unlike the critics) enjoyed the original. It's not as good, but close, and is a worthy sequel.
Had to see it...liked it and still loving the characters.
I wanted to throw up at the awfulness this movie bestowed upon the original.
I wish they had not have made this movie
I wanted to like this movie, but I just couldn't. So much wrong with it and so much that had been done before better. Peter Fonda and that terrible accent was just awful.
Copies way too much of the original, and it is not as funny, but still, the second installment is still entertaining  enough and drives the story forward.
great sequel to the first one
Basically the same kind of feel to the original but still fun

Just got a glimpse of the first one and it looked kinda cool, so I decided to give the sequel a try. This is like Smokin' Aces, but with stupid humor and lame dialogue. Wasn't expecting much and that's just what I got.
Could have been better!
Terrible film. Duffy really made a mess out his story. Sad
The comical aspect ruined the not so good plot. A real disappointment compared to the first. It could have been a lot better if they made it not a comedy.
Really its pretty much the same movie as the first with new characters.  It was good but not Epic like the first one.
Just as before, this is a guilty pleasure movie, its story is pretty bad, but its just a fun cast of characters.
so bad. soooooo bad.

Perhaps a sequel would have worked better when the original was still fresh in Writer/Director Troy Duffy's mind, but the ten-year layoff between films has yielded a picture in The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day that just doesn't pass muster as a follow-up to one of the 1990's most audience-lauded cult classics. While the film retains some trademark Boondock action scenes, there's little else here of value. The characters are flat, the writing is horrendous, the pacing is lacking, and the film just tries far too hard to live up to its predecessor and ultimately falls flat on its face with practically every frame. Indeed, All Saints Day literally wears out its welcome before the first 15 or so minutes, and it's unfortunately one of the lesser movies of 2009 and one of the worst "most anticipated sequels" in generations.
One of the worst movies I have seen in my life.
Helt okej för att vara en uppföljare, lite mycket transportsträckor och lite väl tunn story. Men okej i övrigt.

No where near as compelling as the first or as well written.  I should say that about the first half.  The second half of the movie though definitely keeps you interested though and reminds you why you are taking the time to watch this thing.  First half of the movie definitely feels like a movie written by a white trash, cocky, disrespectful, juvenile minded person that Duffy is.  The second half though seems to be a flash of the rare brilliance that overwhelmed Duffy while he wrote the first movie.  So again first half is ridiculously horrible, second half is a whole different movie more on par with the first.  Rumors of a 3rd are being floated around and supposedly it is actually in the development stage.  The fact that the second one sucked halfway through though and only the second half was worth watching I can't help but feel the 3rd one will be an entire film of crap.  Duffy is toxic in Hollywood because he is so full of himself but yet acts like your typical Boston teenage trash.... too bad he is in his 40s though.  Mark Whalberg used to be the same punk but he soon realized if he wanted a career he had to stop acting like a douche bag punk.  He cleaned up his act, started respecting people and now is an A list celeb.  I haven't heard anything on the Duffy front in several years but I can imagine he is the same immature punk he has been in the past.  Until I hear otherwise that is the truth.  He was a bartender when he got a deal from Miramax to do BDS 1, his head inflated 100 fold.  He acted like he was hot sh** in hollywood.  Would show up to meetings wearing bibs and drunk/hungover from the night before.  he respects no one in Hollywood and as a result Miramax had enough and pulled out of their deal.  No one wanted to touch the boondock saints because of Duffy's juvenile punk personality.  That is why no one heard of the boondock saints until a few years after it hit theaters.  It hardly hit theaters from what I hear.  Something like 5 theaters for 1 week is all it was out for.  It took word of mouth from DVD sales until people started praising it and finally reached cult status.  It's box office take was in the thousands, DVD sales.... $50 mil+.  You'd think a movie that did that well in DVD sales would have production companies chomping at the bit to give duffy a deal to make the second one..... nope.  It to was limited release because no one wanted to work with the childish Duffy.  Granted it made $11+ mil at the box office, it too grossed most of its profit from DVD sales, I think $60 mil or so.  Duffy is the prime example of what not to do when given a chance to actually live out your dreams.  Instead of being grateful he acted like he was too good for Hollywood before he even made a dent in Hollywood.  Instead of focusing on his movie and networking with higher ups or even his peers in Hollywood he just drank at bars with his low life friends.  Networking is the key to success, talent is secondary.  Had Duffy not act like an a** when he got his first deal, which eventually was taken back, and networked within the Hollywood community and studied his craft Saints 2 could've been a lot better.  He could've gotten professional help writing the movie which i think would've made Saints 2 so much better.  Heck, if he showed respect when he got the deal for Boondock Saints 1 Miramax probably would've stayed onboard and that would mean a wide release for the film.  I think Saints 1 could've grossed $100+ mil at the box office had Miramax stayed on, and Duffy would probably actually be a name in Hollywood and he would've followed a similar path that Robert Rodriguez took.  Instead he let his head get too big and as a result few people in HW want to deal with his immaturity and arrogance.  That is why BDS 2 was a noticeable blunder.  In the writing alone you can see Duffy knew how he wanted the climax and resolution to be.  He had no clue though on how to set it up for the first 40 minutes of the movie which is why most of the first half is so pointless and laughably bad.

Using the basic blueprint for what a good sequel should be, The Boondock Saints II may not reinvent the wheel, or even wax it up to make it look shiny, all that much. But it is still a very fun action movie that contains stylish action and funny dialogue that largely succeeds despite it's mundane plot.
Almost as shitty as the first one.
Divertida pélicula de accion
And finally they fall into pieces...
Not as good as the first but a worthy sequel
awesome movie. can't wait on 3 to come out
Not as good as the first...but none the less..pretty damn good

Sean Patrick Flanery, Norman Reedus and Billy Connolly are all great in their roles and the action is still fun, but Boondock Saints II feels like a boring retread of the first one done poorly. Julie Benz gives a terrible imitation of Willem Dafoe's character and the plot is inconsistent, illogical and even boring. Just watch the first Boondock Saints, you'll have a lot more fun

This film was nowhere near as addicting as the first film, but the characters are so funny and interesting that it's hard to avoid watching.  Basically, if you loved the original you can tolerate The Boondocks Saints 2 but don't expect another Cult classic.
Just as good as the first, if not better!!!

I wanted to see this film when it came out but I never did. And now, I regret it. I saw this and unlike the first one, I loved it. It was a lot funnier and awesome to watch Sean Patrick Flannery and Norman Reedus as the Irish vigilante McManus brothers Connor and Murphy return to bring justice to those responsible for the murder of a beloved priest. It was great that director Troy Duffy brought back a lot of the actors from the first one. Like David Ferry (Dolly), Brian Mahoney (Duffy), Bob Marley (Greenly), Gerard Parks (Doc), and David Della Rocco. And as for the new characters: Clifton Collins Jr. (Star Trek) as the wild and sensitive Mexican sidekick Romeo, Julie Benz (Rambo) as the southern and Smeckerâs FBI replacement Eunice Bloom, Judd Nelson (The Breakfast Club) as Don Yakavettaâs son Concezio, and Peter Fonda (3:10 to Yuma) as Louie âThe Romanâ were all terrific. I thought Billy Connolly, who returns as âll Duceâ, was a lot better than he was in the first one. I loved the action, the comedy is hysterical, and there were some sad moments, THE BOONDOCK SAINTS II: ALL SAINTS DAY is one of the greatest sequels Iâve ever seen.

I loved the first one, it is one of my favourite movies Agent Smecker is one of the most memorable characters I have ever seen. This film is set 8 years later so you would hope Troy Duffy could come up with something better. He can't! This is a repeat of the first movie, except it's missing it's most memorable character (who is replaced with an annoying, obviously Smecker replicated Julie Benz as Special Agent Bloom), It's filled with a mocking soundtrack, A dumb character Romeo, who is a worse version of Rocco from the original. I'm not sure why The MacManus Brothers (who are still fun to watch despite the awful material) would trust this random Mexican guy? Makes no sense, instead of actually trying to make a worthy sequel to the original, he tried to remake the original and failed. Check out the first one, leave this one behind.
Not as good as the first movie but still just as badass!!
liked first movie better then this one.. but this wasnt bad either! :)

i love the boondock saints..1 and 2
I lllloooovvve this movie

Esta es una secuela repetitiva e innecesaria, que simplemente se limita en replicar la misma trama del filme original nuevamente. El filme cuenta con Troy Duffy, director y escritor del filme original, pero en lugar de arriesgar con algo más novedoso, simplemente presenta más de lo mismo. Los actores principales del filme original, Sean Patrick Flanery (Chronicles of the Young Indiana Jones) y Norman Reedus (The Walking Dead) regresan, pero como la trama es repetitiva, es muy poco lo que pueden aportar. Aunque me gustó ver a Julie Benz ("Darla" en Buffy, the Vampire Slayer) en un papel importante, su personaje es un evidente esfuerzo de repetir la fórmula presentada por Dafoe en el primer filme, y aunque se esmera en dar una buena actuación, la medida con que se mide es muy alta, ya que como comenté en el review del primer filme, Dafoe se jala una soberbia actuación allí, así que tratar de emularlo es muy, pero muy complicado por no decir imposible. Sin embargo, aunque considero que todo el filme es un desperdicio de tiempo, el desenlace sienta la base para una tercera parte que entiendo será filmada en el 2013, y además la escena final guarda sorpresas que no quiero spoilear que al menos me dejaron con un buen sabor de boca al terminar esta patética secuela.

Remarkably worse than the first.

Completely forgot to write up a review for this movie, but I guess it's ok since I don't think anyone else I know has seen it.  Some might not even knew it existed.  Boondock 2 is a straight up sequel and suffers from all the problems that most sequels often do.  The biggest one being that director Troy Duffy is a straight up ASS-HOLE.  Strangely, my complaints for this movie seem to coincide with my complaints of Transformers 2.  Too much non sense, it's racist, didn't know if it wanted to be a slap stick comedy or balls out action, etc.  The dialogue is so hokey, and they literally bring back every character, no matter how insignificant, sometimes even if that character died.  Didn't matter to Duffy.  Here's the thing: most characters in the movie are over acting and it sucks balls.  Some of the actors are just over the top, and then it kind of works.  Example: three amateur cops that deliver dialogue like pizza delivered under thirty minutes.  Bullshit.  Clifton Collins Jr. plays the replacement sidekick to the Saints and stands out as ridiculously over the top but never amateur.  Advice?  Cast actual actors next time, and not your loser friends.  Troy Duffy revels in the fact that he's the self proclaimed "man's man" that lives life according to John Wayne.  The whole thing's chock full of racial slurs and homophobic remarks.  Duffy's such a douche, but if you loved the first one, there's a couple of dope scenes and shades of funny in there to be mildly entertained.

Totally reeks of awesomeness.  This one takes itself a little bit less seriously then the first movie which is a good direction given the first got a little too preachy.  Awesome jokes and quips throughout, Clifton Collins Jr. kicks ass as their Mexican, and more bad ass shootouts.  Julie Benz is kind of annoying and is no Willem Dafoe, and the plot with the brother's dad got a bit hokey, but a worthy sequel.  And if you haven't see the first, borrow my DVD or Blu-ray :)

100% Total crowd pleaser. The film is a perfect example of creating a feeling like you're revisiting old friends. So much nostalgia hit me watching this film. Not an ounce of the spirit of camaraderie was lost in the sequel and that is easily the movie's greatest strength. Troy Duffy without a doubt has a style and way of filmmaking that too many filmmakers lose. Is he a one trick pony? Who cares!? The film has pretty much the same energy and rock the first had just with older actors.

Maybe not better than the first, but definitely more fun and gleefully violent. Troy Duffy may steal a lot from the likes of Tarantiono, but it can't be denied that no one has mastered the filming of gun fighting to the same degree as himself. Also, for the first time in my life the final acts of a movie suggesting the possibility of a sequel has gotten me pumped a la max, instead of the usual groan of displeasure no matter how good the movie.

This sequel is definitely much weaker than the fantastic original, but I still got a kick out of watching this wacky sequel. There's still plenty of action and humor, making it a fun popcorn action flick. However, this is a sequel that fans of the original film should only rent because it has proven to be a rather divisive sequel.

Storied Director Troy Duffy brings back The Saints for the sequel to his cult classic. When a priest is murdered in a way that frames them, ?the boys? return to Boston to bring justice upon the mob forces responsible.
Boondock II picks up ten years after the first with the MacManus brothers (Sean Patrick Flannery and Norman Redus) living a quiet life on an Irish sheep farm. Back in Boston a priest is killed to bring the brothers out of hiding, unfortunately for those responsible this plan works and the brother return to Boston.
All Saints Day employs the same tone as the first with a combination of comedic banter and over the top action; thankfully the production values on the sequel are vastly superior to that of its predecessor.
Overall All Saints Day has everything a fan of the Original will love, the style of seeing the brothers about to pull off a stylish shootout only to cut to the police and have them explain what happens while the scene is going on is back. They have a new sidekick, this time it?s an over the top Mexican named Romeo played by Clifton Collins Jr to add some comedic levity to the scenes. Billy Connolly?s character II Duce/Poppa Mcmanus is given the Godfather II treatment and we learn how he came to start the family business of killing the wicked. The only drawback to the film is Sean Patrick Flannery looks like he had some plastic surgery done which makes it seem like a different actor is playing his character.
Just like the original it won?t do much at the box office but will surely find its audience on DVD. How can you not enjoy a movie that includes dialog such as this gem of a line uttered by Murphy Mcmanus (Norman Reedus) before a memorable shootout ?Time for some gratuitous F@*#king Violence?

This was really horrible. Although the first one was shoddy from a cinematic perspective, this sequel took the plot, added idiot characters reminiscent of Jar-Jar Binks and tried to make Boondock Saint into a serious movie. If you have the option, please remember the saints in their original context and don't watch this movie.

10 years after the original came around and became something of a cult classic, Troy Duffy finally manages to make a sequel. The bad news is that while this sequel is bigger, it is not better as it is just more of the same.

After a priest is murdered and the blame is pinned on the Saints, the two brothers and their father thus come out of hiding to strike back against Mafiosos all around. Meanwhile, they gain a Mexican buddy to replace Della Rocco, and they are being investigated by yet another FBI agent.

It was nice that they got some characters from the original back and retained their chemistry. This is probably the best thing about this follow-up. As time passed, it has more style applied to it in nearly every facet. The gunfights got cooler, the visuals got sleeker, etc. And the actors really try to work with it as much as they can.

However, a more emphatic style is unable to hide its lack of substance or, better yet, the fact that it's a clone of the original. It reminds us why we watch the original because the original did it so much better. Frankly, this sequel's attempts in emulation backfire upon itself because this makes the movie repetitive and shockingly dull to sit through. The style makes this feel overdone. For a wait as long as this, the filmmakers could've done much better.

Moral of the story: What was cool, fun, and fresh in 1999 is not so much nowadays. If they aspire to make a third one, they better do it right by trying something new with it.

i actually found this one to be more intense compared to the first. i liked the idea that it was more story based/dramatic...but that was about the only good thing. it was basically a re-hashing of what was in the first: lame grindhouse scenes and dream sequences driven by awful looking flashbacks. i found no likable characters in this one, with the majority of them being dry.  Duffy was much better at telling the story through his camera this time, although he still needs some work. the worst part was the female investigator. i have never, in my life, heard an accent that bad, nor seen anyone with such awful direction and movements. the main highlight of this picture were the cameos and the intensified story; i saw this as an overall improvement from what was lacking in the first film, although what made the first film so entertaining  (the characters) was lost in this sequel.

I do however remember that it was one of those "take no prisoners" raw shooters that made you oddly happy over movie violence. :-) This movie tries really hard to reproduce this feeling, but doesn't even come close. The heart of the original is simply missing. And sure, it's nice to see Benz again, but as a stand-in for Dafoe? Sorry kitten, but you could not pull of that one even on your best day.

Still, it's a decent shooter and does provide a decent entertainment of a very specific sort.

This is the very definition of a bad sequel.  It's a literal rehash of everything from the first film with a story obviously designed just to make a sequel but not to continue the story.  The structure of the film is exactly the same, only worse.  It has absurd backstories about its characters and takes the creative aspects from the first film and does them over, signifying a great lack of originality or continuity.  The actors suck, and everything great about the first movie is almost ruined by this one.  So bad acting, bad writing, self-plagiarism, story that makes no sense, Duffy's direction suddenly coming off like a 14 year old who loves classic rock and just figured out how to operate imovie, AND worst of all, it doesn't continue ANYTHING.  It's just another worthless story with morals already explored in the one before it.

Definitely a decent sequel that had me asking for more saints. Their mission is always simple: kill the bad guys. I would love to see the Boondock Saints set loose in Northern Ireland. I think that at the beginning of the movie they are in main land Ireland. They would have a controversial, but amazing movie if they moved their methods to Northern Ireland, especially if they could time travel, and because they are Catholic. Any way, this sequel was fun. Flanery and Reedus do a great job being brothers and make the whole movie worth a look. I read that there is a potential television show out there for the Saints. I think that would be pretty cool. Any way, check out the movie.

111123: Why do sequels always try to do more of everything that was good about the first films? It's never about quantity, it's quality. another very good movie

Gimmicky plot devices. Annoying characters and dialog. The story is decent but the execution is poor. It's a shame.

thought it was a well done film. it keep to the original. Troy duffy is a freak. I even enjoyed the little twists that were thrown into the movie. the only thing I can say bad about the film was the fake ass southern accent

This whole movie feels forced, it is as though one of 'the saints' put a gun to the creators head and demanded a sequel.

The only people who are going to watch this are those who liked the original (which was a great niche action movie 8/10 stars). BSII fails to love up to the original in every way; interesting & entertaining characters are replaced with cheap & annoying ones; old gimmicks are simply rehashed; the leads look old & tired; recurring characters look lost & bewildered; and where the original BS story was simple, tight, & original, BS2's plot is overcomplicated and contrived.

There are some thrills and spills to be had in BSII, but it is difficult to watch something fall so far short from the quality of the original.

On the Fruit-Meter, BSII gets the "SULTANA (or RAISEN)' - The original grape was fresh and juicy, the sequel has lost all the original zesty flavours and has too many wrinkles.
about the same as the first one still worth a watch tho
As good as I thought it would be. Can't wait for the sequel.

who the hell says something has to be original to be good? honestly hasn't originality been exhausted for some time now? good movie. the only complaint was the woman in the movie needed to have her balls removed. if she bragged about herself any more i would have thrown the movie away. the same goes for overexxuberant male actors as well. one that's comparable to this woman would be ice cube in xxx state of the union. appalling.
This film tries to capture lightning in a bottle. It didn't work. It is made by the same film maker but its like he doesn't know what made his first one so good. Stay away.

After 10 years and a failed start the Saints are back. One with a bucket of blood and the other a bucket of nitro. As in usual movie logic the sequal doesn't deliever like the orginal (with the exception of Terminator 2, Godfather 2, and The Dark Knight). And this isn't any different. BUT when you're working with something as amazing as The Boondock Saints as your foundation it's hard. And this is not to say it's a bad movie. Far from it. You just get more of the same equation. Styleized shoot 'em up violence, quick catchy vulgar dialouge, and replays of the action during the police investigation. Old characters are reprised by all the actors. With the addition of hottie Julie Benz, Cliftion Collins Jr, Judd Nelson and acting legend Peter Fonda. You even get a back story on El Duce and quite the open ending for a 3rd installment. Hopefully it won't take another 10 years to get there. If you loved the 1st you won't be disappointed. If you hated the 1st you're just getting more of the same and wouldn't be interested in it anyway. I loved it and plan on buying.
Worth watching, despite the fact that it doesn't live up to the original.
A little more B-movieish, but fans will be pleased. It keeps its style and notches up the humour. A little surprise at the end ;)

It's ever much the gun fetishist's dream as the previous movie but with a script that tries and falls short.  Troy Duffy can very much direct a movie, but he should've spent a little more time boning up the story on this one and less time browsing the arsenal.  Unfortunately, it's just engaging enough to remind you how good the first movie is, but too cheesy to be memorable.
Ok, I have no real complaints about this film although it was a bit slow at times and Julie Benz was atrocious. Good story line that held to the first movie an some great "gratuitous violence"
